Shi Huiyuan, originally surnamed Jia, was a person from Loufan in Yanmen.
When young, he loved books and was outstanding. At the age of thirteen, he followed his uncle Linghu to study in Xuchang and Luoyang.

Therefore, when young, he was a student and extensively studied the Six Classics, especially skilled in the works of Zhuangzi and Laozi. His nature and conduct were magnanimous and broad, and his demeanor and discernment were clear and outstanding. Even the most learned scholars did not deny his profound understanding.
At the age of twenty-one, he wanted to cross the Yangtze River to the east to study with Fan Xuanzi and make an appointment for a secluded life.
At that time, Shi Hu had already died, and the Central Plains were in turmoil. The southern route was blocked, and his wish could not be fulfilled.

At that time, the monk Shi Dao'an established a temple on Mount Taihang and Mount Heng, widely promoting the image of the Dharma, his reputation was very well-known, Yuan then went to take refuge with him.
He paid his respects to him, considering him his true teacher.
Later, he heard An lecturing on the Prajna Sutra.
He suddenly had an awakening and sighed:
The nine streams of Confucianism and Daoism are all chaff and bran.
He then cut his hair and dyed his robes with his younger brother Huichi, entrusting his life to receive the teachings.

Having entered the Way, he was outstanding and not of the common people, always wanting to take charge and uphold the great Dharma as his responsibility, carefully contemplating and reciting it, continuing day and night.
Poor and without resources, he was always lacking in coarse cloth, but his brothers were respectful and diligent, never slacking off.
There was a monk named Tanying who always provided him with the expenses for lamps and candles.
When An heard about this, he was delighted and said:
The Wayfarer truly knows people.
Relying on wisdom and understanding from past causes, he gave rise to the supreme mind for vast eons, thus able to surpass others with spiritual brilliance and have profound insight into the distant.
Master Dao'an often sighed and said:
If the Way is to flow to the Eastern Lands, it lies in Huiyuan!
At the age of twenty-four, he began lecturing and expounding.
Once, a guest listened to the lecture and debated the meaning of true suchness. Going back and forth for a while, his doubts only increased.
Huiyuan then cited the meaning of the Zhuangzi to connect it, and the confused one understood.
After this, Master Dao'an specially allowed Huiyuan not to neglect secular studies.

Dao'an had disciples such as Fa Yu and Tan Hui, who were all brilliant in talent and character, and pure and diligent in their aspirations and deeds. They were all impressed by him. Later, he followed Master Dao'an on a southern tour to Fanhe.

In the ninth year of the Jianyuan era of the pseudo-Qin state, Qin general Fu Pi invaded and expelled Xiangyang. Dao'an was detained by Zhu Xu and was unable to leave. He then divided his disciples and let them go their separate ways.
As they were about to set off, all the senior monks were given instructions, but Yuan did not receive a single word.
Yuan then knelt and said:
To be alone without instruction, I fear it is not the example of others.
An said:
How could someone like you still worry?
Yuan then went south to Jingzhou with dozens of disciples and stayed at Shangming Temple.
Later, he wanted to go to Mount Luofu, but when he reached Xunyang, he saw that Mount Lu was pure and quiet, sufficient for resting the mind. He first stayed at Dragon Spring Hermitage.
This place was very far from water, so Yuan struck the ground with his staff and said:
If this place can be a dwelling, I will make the decayed soil produce a spring.
As soon as he finished speaking, clear springs gushed out, and later they formed a stream.

It means being able to dispel the deep darkness of the ignorant world and open up the mysterious path beyond the realm of transformation. It is about to go with the Way of forgetting both self and things, and go together with the world.
To make those who aspire to the lofty ones appreciate its remaining wind, and those who rinse the flowing water taste its remaining essence.
If so, although the great undertaking has not yet been accomplished, observing its traces of transcendence, the understanding is already vast.

Moreover, the kasaya robe is not the attire of the imperial court, and the alms bowl is not the vessel of the ancestral temple. Åšramaá¹‡as are people outside the dust, and should not pay respect to the king.
Although Xuan stubbornly adhered to his previous views, he was ashamed to immediately comply with others, but when he saw Far's words and meaning, he hesitated and was undecided.
After a while, Xuan usurped the throne and issued a decree saying:
The Buddha's teachings are vast and profound, and I cannot fathom them. I respect the ruler's feelings and therefore pay homage to them.
Now that the matter is in my hands, I should be humble and bright. The monks should no longer pay homage.
Huiyuan then wrote the Treatise on Åšramaá¹‡as Not Bowing to the Ruler, which had five chapters.
The first is Laypeople:

It states that laypeople who uphold the Dharma are subjects who follow the teachings. Their feelings have not changed from worldly customs, and their traces are the same as those within the realm. Therefore, there is love for those who belong to heaven and the propriety of serving the ruler. Propriety and respect have their basis, and thus they are used to establish teachings.
The second is Monastics:
It states that monastics are able to renounce the world and seek their aspirations, and transform worldly customs to reach their path.
Transforming worldly customs means their robes and appearance cannot follow the same propriety as the secular classics. Renouncing the world means they should elevate their traces.
The Venerable One is thus able to rescue the drowning world from the sinking current, and to uproot the profound roots from the heavy eons, far transmitting the ferry of the Three Vehicles.
Near opening the path of humans and gods.

If one man completely perfects his virtue, then the Way will moisten the six relatives, and the grace will flow throughout the world. Even if he does not occupy the position of king or marquis, he will have already harmonized with the ultimate of the emperor and pardoned the people.
Therefore, internally contradicting the heaviness of the heavenly lord, yet not going against filial piety;
Externally lacking the respect of serving the ruler, yet not losing reverence.
Third, Seeking the Ultimate and Not Following Transformation:
It means that those who return to the origin and seek the ultimate do not burden their spirits with birth;
Those who transcend and fall away from the dust-sealed do not burden their lives with emotions. Not burdening their lives with emotions means their lives can be extinguished;
Not burdening their spirits with birth means their spirits can merge.
The merged spirit is the ultimate realm, thus called nirvana.
Therefore, although monks do not bow to the emperor, they are highly regarded for their practice, and although they are not ennobled by the king, they receive his grace.
Fourth, the ultimate principle does not encompass:

It is said that the TathÄgata and the Duke of Zhou and Confucius, although their attainments differ, they secretly influence each other, and although their appearances are different, their ultimate goal must be the same.
Therefore, although their ways differ, their destination is one.
Those who do not encompass the response are those who cannot receive both.
Fifth, the form ends but the spirit does not perish:
It is said that consciousness and spirit roam and gallop, following actions to the east and west.
This is the general idea of the treatise.
From this point on, monks obtained the traces of completely being outside the world.
When Huan Xuan fled west, Emperor An of the Jin returned to the capital from Jiangling. He Wuji, the supporter of the state, advised Yuan to go and pay his respects.
Yuan claimed to be ill and did not go.
The emperor sent an envoy to inquire about his illness. Yuan wrote a letter saying:
Shi Huiyuan bows his head:
The sunny month is warm, I wish your imperial diet is suitable.

I, a poor monk, first suffered from a serious illness, and as I grow old, it has become even worse. I am deeply grateful for your compassionate decree, which has greatly comforted me. The depth of my gratitude and fear is truly a hundredfold in my heart.
Fortunately, I encountered this celebration, but my body cannot move on its own. This feeling and this sigh are truly beyond description.
The imperial decree replied:
In the middle of spring, I am moved by your thoughts, knowing that your illness has not yet improved, and your feelings are lingering.
Last month, I set out from Jiangling, and on the way, there were many bad feelings, delaying me longer than usual. I originally hoped to pass by and see you.
Since the Dharma Master has been nourishing his nature in the mountains and forests, and his illness has not yet healed, there is no chance to meet again, which increases my sighs of regret.
Xie Lingyun of Chen Jun was arrogant and rarely respected by others, but when he met Huiyuan once, he was suddenly awed and convinced.
Huiyuan internally understood the Buddhist principles and externally was good at various writings. All the students of learning relied on him as a model.
At that time, Huiyuan was lecturing on the Sutra on Mourning Garments, and Lei Cizong, Zong Bing, and others all held the scrolls and received the instructions.
Later, Cizong wrote a separate commentary, calling it Lei's Treatise.
Zong Bing then wrote a letter teasing him, saying:
In the past, I and you together received this teaching in person from Master Shi. Now, you title the beginning of the scroll as 'Lei's Treatise'?
His teachings extended to both monks and laypeople, and there were many such cases.
Since Huiyuan settled in Mount Lu for over thirty years, his shadow never left the mountain, and his footsteps never entered the secular world.
Whenever he saw off guests, he always used Tiger Creek as the boundary.

In the first month of the twelfth year of the Yixi era of the Jin dynasty, he began to feel unwell. On the sixth day, he was gravely ill. The virtuous and elderly all bowed their heads and requested to drink fermented bean juice, but he did not allow it.
They further requested to drink rice water, but he did not allow it.
They further requested to drink a beverage made by mixing honey with water, and then ordered a Vinaya master to look up the scriptures to see if it was allowed to drink it or not.
The scroll was not even half finished when he passed away at the age of 83.
His disciples wailed in grief as if they had lost their father or mother;
Monks and laypeople rushed to pay their respects, following one after another.
Yuan, with the emotions of an ordinary person difficult to sever, set a seven-day period of mourning, and ordered that his body be left exposed under a pine tree.
Later, his disciples collected and buried him. The Prefect of Xunyang, Ruan Bao, excavated a cave and opened a tunnel on the western ridge of the mountain.
Xie Lingyun composed a stele inscription, recording his virtuous deeds.
Nanyang Zong Bing also erected a stele at the temple gate.
Originally, Yuan was good at writing prose and poetry, with clear and elegant language. His discussions were refined and concise.
Moreover, his appearance was upright, and his demeanor was relaxed and unconstrained. Therefore, his portrait was painted in the temple, serving as a model for people far and near.
The treatises, prefaces, inscriptions, eulogies, poems, letters, and collections he wrote in ten scrolls, totaling over fifty pieces, were highly regarded by the world.
2 Shi Huichi, Shi Huichi was the younger brother of Huiyuan.
He was profound and silent, with far-reaching thoughts.
At the age of fourteen, he studied books, and what he could learn in one day was equal to others' in one month.
He was good at literature and history, and skilled in writing.
At the age of eighteen, he left home and served together with his elder brother under Dharma Master Dao'an.
He studied extensively in various scriptures and mastered the Tripiá¹­aka.
When An sent Yuan to the east in Xiangyang, Chi also went with him.
He first stayed at Shangming Temple in Jingzhou, and later went to Mount Lu, all following Yuan to stay together.
Chi was eight feet tall, with an outstanding appearance. He always wore leather shoes and a robe that covered half of his calves.
The disciples on Mount Lu were all outstanding, coming and going in the thousands, all regarding Chi as the leader.
Chi had an aunt who was a nun named Dao Yi, who lived in Jiangxia.
Yi heard that the capital was flourishing in Buddhism and wanted to go down to observe the teachings.
Zhi then escorted his aunt to the capital and stayed at Dong'an Temple.
Wang Xun, the General Who Guards the Right of the Jin Dynasty, deeply respected her.
At that time, there was a monk from the Western Regions named Saá¹ƒghabhara, who was good at reciting the Four Ä€gamas. Xun invited him to translate the Madhyama Ä€gama SÅ«tra.
Zhi then collated the text, thoroughly examined and determined it, and later returned to the mountain.

After a short time, Fan Ning, the Prefect of Yuzhang, invited her to lecture on the Lotus SÅ«tra and the Abhidharma. At that time, people from all directions gathered like clouds, coming from a thousand miles away.
Wang Xun wrote a letter to Fan Ning, saying:
Which is better, Master Yuan or Master Zhi?
Fan replied in a letter, saying:
They are truly virtuous brothers.
Wang wrote again, saying:
It is not easy to have someone like the elder brother, let alone a younger brother who is also virtuous.
Wang Gong of Langya, the Governor of Yanzhou, wrote a letter to the monk Sengjian, saying:
What is the virtue of the brothers Yuan and Zhi like?
He replied:
They are the brothers Yuan and Zhi. They are indeed people with the Way.
When KumÄrajÄ«va was in Guanzhong, he admired them from afar and sent a letter to establish friendly relations with them, forming a good friendship.

Later, Zhi heard that the land of Chengdu was fertile and the people were prosperous, and he wished to go there to spread the teachings, and also wanted to visit Mount Emei, shaking his staff on the peaks of Mount Min. He then took leave of Yuan in the third year of Long'an in the Jin dynasty and entered Sichuan.
Yuan tried hard to keep him, but he would not stop.
Yuan sighed and said:
People love to gather, but you enjoy leaving. How is this?
Zhi also said sadly:
If one is attached to emotions and loves to gather, one should not have left home in the first place.
Now that I have cut off desires and seek the Way, I am truly looking forward to the Western Regions.
Then the brothers wiped away their tears, silently sympathized with each other, and parted ways.
They arrived in Jingzhou, and the governor Yin Zhongkan treated them with joy and respect.
At that time, Huan Xuan was also there.

Although Xuan's learning was shallow, his spirit was extraordinary. He was seen as having a unique and unparalleled understanding, and was greatly admired as being incomparable throughout the ages, and they deeply wished to form a bond with him.
Since Zhi was doubtful of his character, he eventually rejected him.
The two men Yin and Huan earnestly wanted to keep him.
Zhi became even more determined to leave. Before leaving, he wrote a letter to Xuan, saying:

Originally, I wanted to stay and recuperate from illness in the mountains of Emei, and observe the transformation of the world beyond the flowing sands. But I cannot bear the thought of setting out, so I will pack my bags and set off.
Xuan received the letter and was saddened, knowing he could not stop him.
So he eventually arrived in Shu and stayed at Longyuan Monastery, greatly promoting the Buddha-Dharma, attracting disciples from all directions who admired his virtue.
The prefect Mao Qu greatly respected him.
At that time, there were monks Huieyan and Sengong.
They were already in Min and Shu, and people respected them.
When Zhi arrived and stayed there, they all looked up to him and admired him from afar.
Those who ascended the hall were all called those who have ascended the dragon gate.
Master Gong had talent and thoughts since childhood, and served as the Buddhist registrar of Shu Prefecture;
Master Yan had extensive knowledge of both Buddhism and non-Buddhist teachings and was long respected by Mao Qu.
Later, Shu person Qiao Zong, taking advantage of the situation of military conflict, attacked and killed Mao Qu, seized control of the Shu region, and styled himself the King of Chengdu.
He then gathered monks to hold a gathering and forced Master Yan to attend.
Yan had no choice but to go.
Since Qu had been his patron in the past, once he was harmed, seeing the situation increased his sorrow, and his appearance became pained. He was then resented by Qiao Zong and consequently killed.
The entire city was in turmoil, and both monastics and laypeople were in danger and fear.
Master Ji took refuge and rested at a temple in Zhixian.
Zong had a son named Daofu, who was even more violent and reckless. He led troops to Zhixian to carry out an investigation and killing.
On his way back, he passed by the temple, and the soldiers and horses bathed in blood. The monks were greatly frightened and all fled in panic.
He held it in front of his room and washed it, his expression unchanged.
Daofu went straight to Zhi's side. Zhi snapped his fingers and scooped up water, calm and composed as usual.
Fu was ashamed and sweating with remorse. He left the temple and said to those around him:
The great man is indeed different from the crowd.

Later, when the region was peaceful, he returned to Longyuan Temple, lecturing, holding assemblies, and repenting, becoming more diligent with age. He died in the temple in the eighth year of Yixi in the Jin dynasty, at the age of seventy-six.
At the end of his life, he bequeathed instructions to earnestly uphold the precepts, telling his disciples:
The sutra says:
Precepts are like level ground, where myriad wholesome deeds arise.
Whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down, you should be careful.
He entrusted the scriptures in the east wing to his disciple Daohong;
The Dharma canon in the west wing to his disciple Tanlan.
Hong had pure and sharp conduct, while Lan had a spiritual and natural understanding. They both followed the teacher's tracks.
3 Shi Huiyong, Shi Huiyong, whose surname was Pan, was a person from Hebei.

At the age of twelve, he left home and served the Å›ramaá¹‡a Zhu Tanxian as his teacher. Later, he also received the Dharma master Dao'an as his teacher. He originally made an appointment with Huiyuan to build a dwelling on the peak of Mount Luofu.
Since Huiyuan was detained by Dao'an, Huiyong wanted to first cross the Five Peaks.
When passing through Xunyang, the local people Tao Fan earnestly requested him to stay. Thus, he temporarily stayed at Xilin Temple on Mount Lu.
Since his disciples gradually increased and Huiyuan also built [the temple], he finally intended to stay there.

Huiyong's virtue and purity were natural, and he disciplined his mind and restrained himself. His words always had a smile, and his speech did not harm others. He loved the scriptures and was good at lecturing. He ate vegetarian food and wore coarse clothes, usually spending his years like this.
He also separately built a thatched hut on the peak, and whenever he wanted to meditate, he would go and stay there.
At that time, those who came to his room all smelled an unusual fragrance.
In the monastery, there was always a tiger. If people were afraid, they would drive it up the mountain. After the people left, it would become docile again.
Yong once went out of the town and returned to the mountain late in the evening, arriving at Wu Bridge.
The commander of Wu Bridge was drunk and blocked Yong's way on horseback, not allowing him to leave.

As it was getting late, Yong pointed at the horse with his staff from a distance, and the horse became startled and ran away. The commander fell to the ground. Yong supported and comforted him back to the camp, where he fell ill.
The next morning, he went to the temple and apologized to Yong.
Yong said:
This was not my original intention. I'm afraid it was done by the deity of the precepts.
The laypeople and monks heard about this and many turned to him with faith.
Later, He Wuji, the General Who Pacifies the South, became the governor of Xunyang. Tao Yuan invited him to Hu Creek and requested Yong and Huiyuan.
Huiyuan had long held a famous reputation and was also elegant in talent and virtue. He was followed by over a hundred people, all dignified and orderly.
His lofty words and elegant discussions were all admirable.

Yong went alone, and later arrived, wearing a coarse robe and straw sandals, holding a staff and alms bowl, yet his demeanor was calm and composed, pure and unassuming. The assembly all respected his integrity and simplicity, and revered him even more.
Huiyuan was respected by many, and admired Yong's lofty practice. He personally acted with humility and respect, hoping for profound blessings.
Yong was strict in his practice of austerity, vowing to be reborn in the Western Paradise.

In the tenth year of Yixi of the Jin dynasty, he encountered a serious illness, yet he was even more diligent in observing the precepts. Although he was bedridden and suffering, his complexion was cheerful.
After a short while, he suddenly adjusted his robe, put his palms together, sought his sandals, and wanted to rise, as if he saw something.
The assembly was all startled and asked him, he replied:
The Buddha has come.
As soon as he finished speaking, he passed away, at the age of eighty-three.
Monks and laypeople on the mountain all smelled a strange fragrance for seven days before it ceased.
At that time, there was also Shi Sengrong on Mount Lu, who was also known for his rigorous practice and spiritual abilities, and was able to subdue ghosts and spirits.
Shi Sengji, Shi Sengji, it is unknown where he was from.
During the Taiyuan period of the Jin dynasty, he came to Mount Lu and studied under Master Huiyuan.
He thoroughly studied the various scriptures, both large and small, as well as the classics, history, and mathematics, and grasped their profound principles.
When he was just over thirty years old, he left the city to start lecturing, and became a leading teacher.
Huiyuan often said:
You are the one who will propagate the Buddha's teachings with me!
Later, after staying on the mountain for a short time, he suddenly became seriously ill. He earnestly faced the Western direction and visualized AmitÄbha.
Huiyuan gave Sengji a candle and said:
You can set your mind on the Pure Land and race against the dripping of the hourglass.
Sengji held the candle on the table, his thoughts undisturbed. He also invited the monks to gather at night to chant the Sutra of Immeasurable Life.
At the fifth watch, Ji gave the candle to his classmate and asked him to distribute it among the monks.

Then he slept for a while and dreamed that he was holding a candle, flying through the air, seeing AmitÄbha Buddha, who placed him in his palm and took him all over the ten directions. He suddenly woke up and told those attending him about the dream.
He was both sad and comforted. He realized that his four elements were free from illness and suffering.
At the end of the night, he suddenly asked for his shoes, stood up, and looked up into the sky as if he saw something.
After a while, he lay down again, his complexion even more joyful. He said to those beside him:
I am leaving.
Then he turned to his right side and his breath ended, at the age of forty-five.
Shi Fayan, also known as Cijing, was a disciple of Master Yuan. His place of origin is unknown.
He practiced good precepts, lectured on various sutras, and also practiced meditation. He was good at guiding the ignorant, pulling them away from evil and returning them to the right path.
During the Yixi period of the Jin dynasty, there was a tiger disaster in Xinyang County.
There was a large shrine tree in the county, under which a shrine was built.
The residents on both sides numbered in the hundreds. Those killed by tigers were one or two every night.
An once traveled through the county and stayed in this village in the evening.
The people feared the tigers and closed their doors early.
An went straight under the tree and sat in meditation all night.
At dawn, he heard a tiger carrying a person and throwing it to the north of the tree.
Seeing An, it was as if it was happy and surprised, and it jumped and crouched in front of An.
An spoke the Dharma and gave it precepts. The tiger squatted on the ground and did not move. After a while, it left.
In the morning, the villagers chased the tiger to under the tree. Seeing An, they were greatly surprised and considered him a divine person.
They spread the word throughout the county, and the scholars and laypeople revered him.
The disaster of tigers was thus pacified. The temple of the deity was changed to Anli Temple. The fields and gardens on the left and right were all donated for the use of the assembly.
Later, when he wanted to make a painting and needed copper for the green color, he was unable to obtain it.
At night, he dreamed of a person who said, Under this bed, there are copper bells.
Upon waking, he immediately dug and found two pieces. He then used the copper to make the green color for the image.
Later, he donated the copper to help Yanzhou make a Buddha image. The remaining piece was borrowed by Xiong Wuhua, the Prefect of Wuchang, to be viewed, and he kept it.
Later, An did not know where he ended up.
Shi Tanyong, whose surname was Yang, was a person from Guanzhong.
He served in the pseudo-Qin government up to the rank of General of the Guards.
He was eight feet tall and had a heroic and martial spirit surpassing others.
In the eighth year of Taiyuan, he followed Fu Jian in attacking the south, but was defeated by the Jin army. When he returned to Chang'an, he became a monk under Master An.
After Huiyuan passed away, he went south to Mount Lu and served Huiyuan as his teacher.
He was well-versed in both Buddhist and non-Buddhist scriptures and treatises, and was dedicated to propagating the Dharma, not shunning fatigue or hardship.

Later, he went to the capital on behalf of Huiyuan to deliver a letter to KumÄrajÄ«va. For more than ten years, he was like a drum or flag, swaying like a mountain peak, strong and courageous, and never failed in his missions.
Sengjian of the Daochang Temple in the capital admired his virtue and understanding and invited him to return to Yangzhou, but Huiyong, considering Huiyuan's advanced age, did not carry out the plan.

However, Huiyuan had many disciples with spiritual abilities and lofty conduct, and feared that they might not respect and revere him later on. Thus, he used a minor pretext to banish Huiyong from the mountain.

Huiyong obeyed the order and left the mountain, without any resentment or displeasure. He then built a thatched hut to the southwest of the mountain and, together with his disciple Tan Guo, contemplated the Chan teachings.
Once, Tan Guo dreamed that a mountain deity requested to receive the five precepts. Guo said:
The family teacher is here, you can go ask him.

Later, after a short while, Yong saw a person wearing a single robe and cap, with a windswept appearance and dignified bearing, accompanied by about twenty followers, requesting to receive the five precepts.
Yong, considering the previous dream, knew it was the mountain deity, so he expounded the Dharma and bestowed the precepts.
The deity offered foreign-made knives, bowed in reverence, took leave, and suddenly disappeared.
On the day of Yuan Lin's death, they rushed to the place, wailing and lamenting, their grief deeply felt.
Later, he went to Jingzhou and passed away at Zhulin Temple.
Shi Daofu Shi Daofu was a person from Wu State. He left home at a young age and became a disciple of Zhi Faqi of Tai Temple.
From a young age, he had literary talent and was diligent in studying.
Later, he entered Mount Lu with like-minded monks Sengqian, Daoliu, and others for seven years. They all received precepts in the mountains, each following their studies, making daily progress.
Yuan often said that Zu and others were easy to enlighten, and if they were all like this, he would no longer worry about future generations.
Yuan died at the age of twenty-eight, and Yuan sighed and said:
These disciples were all talented and virtuous, their clear understanding renewed day by day. To bear this and pass away, how painful!
Daoliu compiled the catalog of various sutras, which was not completed. Zu finished it and it is circulated in the world today.
Later, Zu returned to Waguan Temple in the capital to lecture. Huan Xuan often went to listen and said to others:
Daozu's later development surpasses Master Yuan, but he is not as knowledgeable in Confucianism.
When Xuan became the regent and wanted to make monks pay respect to the king, Zu then declined and returned to Taisui Temple in Wu.
After some time, Xuan usurped the throne and ordered the prefecture to send Zu to the capital.
Zu claimed illness and did not go, so he cut off contact with worldly affairs and lectured on the Way all day long.
He died in the first year of Yuanxi of the Jin dynasty at the age of seventy-two.
Far had a disciple named Huiyao, who also understood sutras and vinaya, but was especially good at ingenious thinking.

There were no water clocks in the mountains, so he set up a twelve-petaled lotus flower in the water, and as the flowing waves turned, he used it to determine the twelve hours, with no error in the time.
He also once made a wooden kite that flew hundreds of steps.
Far also had disciples Tan Shun and Tan Chen, who were both renowned for their doctrinal studies.
Shun was originally from Huanglong. He began studying under Master Shi when young, and later returned to study under Far. He ate vegetarian food and had virtue and practice.
Liu Zun, the Cavalry General of the Southern Barbarians, established Zhulin Temple in Jiangling and invited Far to start it.
Far sent him there.
Chen was also pure and elegant, with a style of his own. He annotated the Vimalakirti Sutra and wrote the Exhaustion and Penetration Treatise, etc.

There were also more than a hundred people such as Fayou, Daoheng, and Daoshu, who either had profound understanding of the meaning, or were able to support the various affairs of the assembly, or had pure and lofty precepts, or had profound meditation, all of whom were famous in the world and transmitted their teachings to the present day.
Shi Sengji, Shi Sengji, whose surname was Fu, was a person from Niyang in northern China, the eldest son of Xia, the magistrate of Hejian in the Jin dynasty.
He left home at a young age and stayed at Daji Temple in Chang'an, becoming a disciple of Dharma Master Hongjue.
Hongjue was also a Dharma master of the time. Sengji first studied under him, and later traveled between Qing, Si, Fan, and Zhuo.
He was proficient in the Six Classics and the Tripiá¹­aka, and was strict in observing the precepts. He was able to uphold the Buddha's teachings.
Yao Chang and Yao Xing admired his reputation early on and had long respected him. When they usurped power in Guanzhong, they deeply respected him.

Since Yao Xing had deep faith in the Three Jewels and greatly promoted the great teachings, he held assemblies and set up vegetarian feasts, with smoke canopies layered upon each other. He caused those who aspired to the Way and renounced the world to be half of the ten households.
Since KumÄrajÄ«va entered the Guanzhong region, distant monks gathered again. As there were many monks and nuns, there were some transgressions. Xing said:
Ordinary monks who have not yet attained the forbearance of suffering, how can they be without faults?
If faults are not investigated, faults will only increase. It is appropriate to establish a leader of the monks to clear up the great expectations.
Thus, he issued a decree, saying:
Since the great Dharma moved east, it has flourished now. As there are already many monks and nuns, a leader is needed to proclaim the distant principles and save the declining tradition.
Master Sengrui, whose studies were excellent in his early years and whose virtue flourished in his later years, can be the leader of the monks in the country.
Master Sengqian, who cultivated both meditation and wisdom, will be the director of the assembly.
Fasheng and Huibin will jointly manage the monk records.
They will be provided with carriages, sedan chairs, and servants.
The Imperial Attendant provided them with stipends, and each was given a sheep cart and two attendants. Xuan and others were also given generous provisions.
They worked together in simplicity and frugality, fully satisfying the expectations of the times. The five groups of Buddhists were respectful and pure, never negligent in the six periods of the day.
In the seventh year of Hongshi, the emperor ordered that they be given personal attendants and white robes, each with thirty people.
The establishment of the Sangha-dharma master began with Xuan.
Xuan himself walked, using carts to provide for the elderly and sick. The offerings he received were always used for the needs of the assembly.
Although he was already in his autumn years, he tirelessly lectured on the sutras and vinaya, exhorting the assembly.
In the last year of Hongshi, he passed away in Chang'an Temple at the age of seventy.
Shi Daorong of Chang'an Temple in the capital during the Liu Song Dynasty Shi Daorong was a person from Linlu, Jichun. He left home at the age of twelve.
His teacher loved his spiritual appearance and first ordered him to study outside. He went to the village to borrow the Analects.
In the end, he did not bring it back, but had already memorized it there.
The master borrowed the original text again to review it, not missing a single word. Having sighed in admiration, he considered it extraordinary. Thus, he indulged in his studies.
By the time he reached adulthood, his talent and understanding were outstanding. He had a deep understanding of the scriptures and treatises of both Buddhism and non-Buddhism.
He heard that KumÄrajÄ«va was in Guanzhong, so he went to consult with him.
KumÄrajÄ«va saw him and thought highly of him, telling Yao Xing:
I saw Master Fu yesterday, and he is also a remarkable and intelligent Buddhist disciple.
Yao Xing summoned him and praised him highly. He ordered him to enter the Xiayuan to participate in the revision and translation.
He requested KumÄrajÄ«va to translate the Bodhisattvas' Code of Conduct, which is now circulated in the world.
Later, when the Madhyamaka-Å›Ästra was translated, only two scrolls were completed. Fu immediately lectured on it, analyzing the text and thoroughly understanding the beginning and end.
KumÄrajÄ«va also ordered Fu to lecture on the newly translated Lotus Sutra.
KumÄrajÄ«va listened to it himself and sighed:
The revival of the Buddha's teachings lies in Fu.
Soon, a Brahmin from the country of Simhala, who was intelligent, eloquent, and well-versed in many Western scriptures, was revered as the patriarch of non-Buddhist teachings in that country.
Hearing that Kumarajiva was in Guanzhong, widely propagating the Buddha Dharma, he said to his disciples:
Can we allow the teachings of Shakyamuni to be transmitted exclusively in China, while our true teachings do not reach the Eastern lands?
Thus, he rode a camel carrying books and entered Chang'an.
Yao Xing saw that his mouth and eyes were crooked and was somewhat deceived by him.
The Brahmin then said to Xing:
The ultimate Way has no fixed direction, each revering its own principles. Now I request to compete in eloquence with the monks of Qin, following whoever is superior, to transmit their teachings.
Xing immediately agreed.
At that time, the monks in Guanzhong looked at each other in dismay, none daring to accept the challenge.
Kumarajiva said to Dao Rong:
This non-Buddhist is exceptionally intelligent, and if we debate with him, he will surely win. If the unsurpassed great way is in our group but is defeated, it is truly lamentable.
